repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Built-in Sphinx RST roles: https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/roles.html#role-program
Explicit external refs: https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/extensions/intersphinx.html#role-external

`pycon` code highlighting is for REPL sessions.
`console` is for terminal sessions (it differentiates lines starting with a prompt like `$` from the output)

Demo/preview: https://cython--6550.org.readthedocs.build/en/6550/src/userguide/source_files_and_compilation.html

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -464,6 +460,8 @@ import mechanism of CPython.
 Create a new C file to integrate the extension modules and add this
 macro to it::
 
+.. code-block:: c
+

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
as follows, replacing ``some_module_name`` with the name of the module:

.. code-block:: c

```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -475,6 +473,8 @@ If you are only targeting Python 3.x, just use ``PyInit_`` as prefix.
 Then, for each of the modules, declare its module init function
 as follows, replacing ``some_module_name`` with the name of the module::
 
+.. code-block:: c
+

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
the name of each of the modules:

.. code-block:: c

```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -488,6 +488,8 @@ with :c:func:`Py_Initialize()`, you need to initialise the modules at runtime
 using the :c:func:`PyImport_AppendInittab()` C-API function, again inserting
 the name of each of the modules::
 
+.. code-block:: c
+
